黄金时段。即使您从事风景摄影的时间不长，您也一定听说过这个词。作为摄影师，我们从事捕捉光线的工作，而它很少能比清晨或傍晚阳光柔和的金色光线更好。

在这个通常持续一个小时左右的窗口期间，光线呈现出一种超凡脱俗的品质。它用温暖的色调笼罩着风景，增添了一天中其他任何时间都找不到的柔和感和深度感。

不幸的是，拍摄令人叹为观止的黄金时段风景照片并不像将相机对准相机然后点击鼠标那么简单。在日出和日落前后工作会带来几个主要挑战，为了确保出色的图像，您需要应用一些技巧和技巧。这就是我整理这篇文章的原因 - 帮助您释放大自然最神奇时光的全部潜力！

下面，我分享了各种有用的建议，包括装备推荐、理想的相机设置以及利用绚丽光线的技巧。因此，如果您准备好开始拍摄保证让您心跳加速的阳光普照的风景，那就让我们开始吧！

1.注意光线的方向

在拍摄令人惊叹的黄金时段风景照片时，了解光线的方向是关键。在这个神奇的时刻，太阳低垂在天空，为大地投下温暖的光芒。但事情是这样的：根据太阳的位置，景观将从不同的角度照射，创造出可以改变您的图像的独特照明效果。

让我们分解一下。需要考虑三个主要照明方向：前光、背光和侧光。当光线来自前方时，会出现前光，直接照亮场景。这种效果通常更直接和更具描述性，以清晰的方式展示景观。

另一方面，侧光发生在光线从侧面射入时，会产生美丽的阴影、强调纹理并增加场景的深度。然后我们有背光，光线来自主体后面，这是一种引人注目的艺术选择，可以制作迷人的图像。

虽然许多风景摄影师都被逆光和侧光所吸引，因为它们具有戏剧性的效果，但请不要低估前光的力量。它可以产生同样令人惊叹的效果，并让您捕捉到风景的所有光彩。

关键是到了你所在的位置要注意太阳的方位。观察它如何影响景观，并考虑最适合您对每个场景的创意愿景的照明方向。

2.寻找一些云

想要制作令人惊叹的黄金时段风景照片？云可以成为将您的图像从普通提升到非凡的额外成分。他们拥有非凡的能力，可以将乏味的图像转变成具有质感和空灵美感的迷人展示。

当然，也有乌云密布之类的！完全阴云密布的天空通常会降低照片的强度。你想要的是部分多云的天空，这将为你的作品注入大量的戏剧性和魔力。

在开始您的摄影冒险之前，有必要查看天气预报以测量所需位置的云量。但是，如果您发现自己在黄金时段面对万里无云的天空，请不要失望。相反，尝试探索更多非常规镜头，例如以简单为中心的极简主义构图。

请记住，即使在没有云的情况下，黄金时段的光线仍然可以发挥其魔力！

3.带上三脚架

如果您计划在黄金时段拍摄， 坚固的三脚架将成为您值得信赖的伙伴。在这个神奇的时刻，随着太阳在天空中下沉，光线变得越来越弱。如果您不相应地调整相机设置，这可能会导致图像曝光不足。补偿逐渐减弱的光线的一种方法是延长快门速度。但是，在没有稳定的三脚架的情况下这样做可能会导致拍摄中不必要的模糊。

现在，我知道您可能在想什么：三脚架可能很笨重并且携带起来很麻烦。但好处远远超过任何轻微的不便。除了确保您的照片保持清晰之外，三脚架还会迫使您放慢速度并仔细考虑每个构图。您甚至可能会发现使用三脚架可以提升您的整体摄影体验。

当然，如果您发现自己没有三脚架，也可以探索其他选择。您可以通过增加ISO或扩大光圈来保持相对较快的快门速度，尽管这些调整确实需要权衡取舍。提高 ISO 会引入噪声伪影，而加宽光圈会使焦平面变窄，从而导致场景的部分模糊。因此，虽然三脚架不是必需品，但我强烈推荐它！

4.提前侦察地点

要充分利用稍纵即逝的黄金时段光线，必须提前侦察您的位置。这使您可以熟悉环境，发现潜在的构图，并预测太阳光将如何与景观相互作用。

如果您计划在清晨拍摄，侦察就变得更加重要，因为您需要在黑暗中寻找构图并设置设备。

考虑在计划拍摄前分配时间参观该地点。可以提前几天或几个小时（如果您在晚上拍摄）。在您的侦察之旅中，注意吸引您眼球的各种主题。可视化阳光将如何绘制场景，带出纹理和投射阴影。

通过熟悉地点，您将自信地接近黄金时段，并更好地捕捉真正非凡的图像。

5.考虑在日出时醒来

虽然许多摄影师在日落前后出发，但设置闹钟并冒险去见证日出的神奇时刻有很大的好处。这是一个世界非常宁静的时刻，黎明柔和的光线在风景上投射出微妙的光芒。

在日出时拍摄的最大优势之一是它提供的孤独感。当世界其他地方都在沉睡时，您会发现自己沉浸在宁静的环境中，不受人群和熙熙攘攘活动的干扰。这种孤独感不仅可以增强您的创作专注力，还可以让您捕捉场景而不必担心人们不小心进入您的画面。

除了宁静的氛围外，与一天中的其他时间相比，早晨的风通常更少。这意味着您有更好的机会捕捉到水体中原始的倒影，为您的景观构图增添一层额外的美丽和宁静。

另外，亲眼目睹日出本身真的很神奇。这是一种非凡的体验，可以将您与自然世界的美丽和韵律联系起来——所以不要害怕早点起床，享受在日出时拍摄的独特奖励！

6.使用正确的光圈和快门速度

设置合适的光圈和快门速度对于拍摄令人惊叹的黄金时段风景照片至关重要。这是我的建议：

要保持整个场景清晰，请选择窄光圈。通常，当您的构图不涉及非常靠近相机的元素时，f/8 效果很好。但是，如果有突出的前景元素，请考虑使用 f/11 或更高的光圈。但要注意不要超过 f/16；否则，您可能会因衍射而变得模糊。

说到快门速度，由于光线减弱，在黄金时段通常需要更长的曝光时间。如果你有三脚架，你可以使用更长的快门速度而不用担心相机抖动。在手动模式下，您可以借助相机取景器中的曝光条设置快门速度。或者，如果您使用光圈优先模式，相机会自动选择合适的快门速度以获得曝光良好的图像。

专业提示：不要回避尝试使用超长快门速度来捕捉水或云的迷人运动。通过将光圈缩小到 f/16 左右并保持 ISO 100，您可以在日出和日落时获得相对较慢的快门速度。

最后，如果您想要更长的快门速度或发现自己在太阳稍高时拍摄， 中性密度滤镜可以改变游戏规则。它会减少光线的流入，防止过度曝光并允许延长曝光时间。

7.使用GND滤镜或HDR技术

在黄金时段，您经常会遇到亮度变化很大的场景。这种黑暗阴影和明亮天空的组合可能会对相机的传感器构成挑战，从而难以在单张照片​​中捕捉到所有细节。幸运的是，您可以采用两种技术来克服这一障碍。

一种选择是使用渐变中性密度 (GND) 滤镜。它们专门设计用于平衡天空和前景之间的曝光。通过将滤镜的较暗部分放在天空上方，您可以降低亮度级别，同时保持前景适当曝光。 GND 过滤器非常有效，但它们的设置可能有点麻烦并且需要仔细定位。

或者，您可以尝试高动态范围 (HDR) 技术。通过这种方法，您可以拍摄一系列不同曝光级别的照片，通常是包围式拍摄以捕捉高光、中间调和阴影中的细节。稍后，您可以使用 Lightroom Classic 等后处理软件合并这些照片，从而将每张图像中正确曝光的区域混合成一张最终照片。 HDR 可能是一个可行的选择，并迅速成为专业人士的最爱。

GND 过滤器提供相机内解决方案，而 HDR 技术提供后处理解决方案。这两种方法都有其优点，因此值得研究以找到适合您的风格和喜好的方法。

请记住，目标是实现平衡的曝光，使天空和前景都保留其细节。通过使用 GND 滤镜或 HDR 拍摄，您可以克服相机动态范围的限制，捕捉黄金时段风景的全部美景。因此，无论您喜欢过滤器的动手方法还是 HDR 的后期处理技巧，这些技术都将成为您摄影武器库中的宝贵工具。

8. 尝试一些风景剪影

正如我在上一节中解释的那样，风景摄影通常围绕着捕捉前景和天空中的复杂细节。虽然这些图像无疑令人惊叹，但如果不使用滤镜或 HDR 技术，某些场景很难拍摄。如果您只想享受一些简单的摄影怎么办？

这就是剪影照片的魔力所在。您可以专注于捕捉美丽天空下的风景剪影，而不是追求完美的细节。

要创建剪影，请定位自己，使天空的明亮部分成为背景。构图，确保要突出的景观元素突出。现在，锁定明亮天空的建议曝光。手动模式特别适合这种技术，但光圈优先也可以很好地发挥作用。

拍完照片后，请在相机的 LCD 屏幕上查看。一个成功的剪影将导致黑暗的前景和详细的天空，形成迷人的对比。如果曝光不理想，请不要气馁。调整曝光补偿或快门速度，直到获得所需的结果。

剪影照片可以为您的作品集增添一丝神秘感。该方法让您可以专注于景观的形状和轮廓，并创建视觉上引人注目的图像，唤起情感并激发观众的想象力。

9. 不要忘记对黄金时段的风景进行后期处理

黄金时段的灯光之美是不可否认的，但要真正释放风景照片的全部潜力，花时间通过后期处理来增强它们是至关重要的。在这里您可以拍摄已经令人惊叹的图像并将它们提升到一个全新的水平。

后期处理黄金时段风景的第一步是使用白平衡。通过调整色温和色调滑块，您可以获得更自然的外观，甚至可以特意创建更冷或更暖的色调来提升图像的整体氛围。

接下来，注意高光和阴影中的细节。黄金时段的场景通常具有较宽的动态范围、较深的阴影和明亮的天空，这可能会导致这两个区域的细节丢失。令人高兴的是，您可以使用后处理工具来恢复丢失的细节，确保图像的重要元素曝光良好。

颜色分级也是一种强大的技术，可以增强黄金时段风景的深度和戏剧性。通过调整色调，您可以创建独特且个性化的外观。尝试不同的颜色组合，找到能够唤起您想要的情绪并强化您所追求的氛围的组合。

最后，考虑应用微妙的晕影将观众的眼睛推向图像的主要主题。但是，请注意不要过度。克制是保持自然和平衡外观的关键。

专业提示：前往黄金时段探险时，我强烈建议使用 RAW 格式拍摄。与 JPEG 相比，RAW 文件包含更多数据，并且在后期处理过程中可以更灵活地调整图像的各个方面。这使您能够在不牺牲图像质量的情况下进行调整，并根据需要恢复细节。

请记住，后处理本身就是一种艺术形式，没有放之四海而皆准的方法。花时间去尝试，发展你自己的编辑风格，并忠于你的艺术视野。

10.日落后继续拍摄

傍晚的黄金时段非常适合风光摄影师。然而，当太阳滑落到地平线以下时，魔法并没有消失。事实上，就在黄金时段结束后，一场迷人的转变发生了。天空呈现出凉爽的蓝色调，宁静柔和的光线营造出一种奇妙的空灵氛围。这段时间被称为蓝色时刻，也是风景摄影的另一个好时机。

虽然蓝色时刻呈现出其独特的挑战，但它提供了一个机会来捕捉完全不同类型的风景照片。照明非常微妙和柔和，为您的场景营造出宁静的氛围。要充分利用这美好的时光，请记得带上您值得信赖的三脚架。逐渐减弱的光线意味着稳定的基础对于避免拍摄模糊至关重要。

如果您计划在这段时间进行射击，侦察就变得更加重要。随着光线的减弱，很容易忽略重要的细节或错过潜在的主题。花点时间事先熟悉一下地点，这样即使在太阳落山后，您也可以轻松导航并识别关键元素。

所以当晚上黄金时段结束时，不要收拾行装。多呆一会儿，让自己沉浸在蓝色时刻的迷人美景中。捕捉宁静的氛围，让您的照片传达宁静和迷人的感觉！

黄金时段风景摄影：最后的话

你有它！我们已经涵盖了一大堆黄金时段风景摄影技巧，它们将使您的技能达到新的高度，因此请确保将它们牢记在心，并在下次拍摄日出或日落时应用它们。

记住，这个神奇的时刻转瞬即逝，所以不要浪费每一刻。早起，追逐日落，尝试不同的设置，不要害怕打破规则和尝试新技术。

另外，不要在黄金时段消失后收拾行李！在宁静的蓝色时刻继续拍摄，看着世界变成柔和、空灵的迷人王国。你不会后悔的！

1.慎重选择时间地点

在捕捉与孩子们的珍贵时刻时，时机就是一切。我从经验中了解到，拍照的最佳时间通常是在精神焕发的小睡和吃点零食之后。那是孩子们最快乐、最合作的时候！

现在，让我们谈谈照明时序的重要性。避免在正午烈日炎炎的室外拍摄。刺眼的光线会投射出不讨人喜欢的阴影，你的照片会显得强烈而对比鲜明。相反，应该在黄金时段拍摄，那是太阳落在地平线上并散发出温暖柔和光芒的神奇时刻。如果您确实发现自己在正午时分无法拍摄，请寻找一些阴凉的地方使光线均匀，并考虑使用反光镜。

选择正确的位置也很重要。在户外工作非常棒，因为它为孩子们提供了充足的空间来自由走动。此外，您还可以利用公园和森林中美丽的自然背景，那里的树叶和鲜花增添了额外的魅力。

另一方面，如果由于特定的设置要求或天气条件而必须在室内工作，请不要担心。只需确保您有足够的空间容纳小孩子们无穷无尽的精力并尝试不同的镜片。您不想被困在一个狭小的空间里——它会束缚您的风格并限制您的创意可能性。

2. 做好准备（但要准备好即兴创作）

您和孩子们都希望拍照过程能够顺利、快速地进行。毕竟，孩子们的耐心并不出名！如果您花太多时间摆弄相机或检查不同的背景，他们会感到无聊、烦躁，并且比您说“奶酪”更快地失去兴趣。

这就是为什么做好准备是关键。在开始之前，请为相机准备好充满电的电池。确保您有多个存储卡并拨入基本设置。整理好所有装备，以便您可以专注于最重要的事情：捕捉那些令人心碎的微笑和顽皮的咯咯笑声。

哦，别忘了道具！在拍摄对象等待时疯狂地寻找野餐篮或椅子是灾难的根源。因此，请准备好您的道具并且易于取用。这里有一个专业提示：将所有玩具隐藏起来，直到需要它们，这样您就可以在适当的时候给小孩子们一个惊喜（并防止他们在拍摄的其余部分分心！）。

如果您在具有不同人像背景的工作室中工作，请提前计划并决定使用它们的顺序。确保它们都已设置好并准备就绪。如果您在户外拍摄，请提前寻找各种背景，并大致了解何时在它们之间转换。

当然，我们都知道孩子和计划并不总是混在一起。因此，如果您精心组织的会议偏离了轨道，请不要担心。那时您需要拥抱意想不到的事物并顺其自然，根据需要即兴创作以捕捉那些真实而神奇的时刻。

3.列一个清单

在上一节中，我们介绍了计划要点，例如准备装备和侦察地点。现在让我们更进一步，讨论如何制定一个游戏计划来捕捉那些完美的画面。

首先，记下您想要确定的镜头列表。你可以包括一些摆姿势的照片，但不要忘记将它与真正捕捉到你的小主题本质的坦率肖像混合在一起。让他们做他们自己吧，因为让我们面对现实吧，那些 Pinterest 上完美的姿势可能行不通——这完全没关系！

想一想他们可以进行的各种活动，例如坐着、站着、玩耍，甚至是满心欢喜地狂奔。寻找灵感和主题，但请记住，这一切都是为了捕捉他们的独特个性。通过考虑一些您可以尝试的有趣活动来提前计划，并准备一些备用选项，例如零食或娱乐电话。如果你和别人的孩子一起工作，只要确保你得到了父母的批准。

再次重申，保持列表的灵活性并在需要时准备好将其扔到一边是很重要的。有时最好的时刻自然而然地发生，你不想因为你的计划过于严格而错过那些宝石！

4.获得增援

孩子们就像小能量球，他们并不总是对着镜头玩得很开心。所以，如果你能摆动它，请呼叫一些后援！无论您是为自己的孩子拍照还是与客户合作，多一双手都可以改变游戏规则。

你可信赖的伙伴应该站在你身后，而不是站在一边。目标？当孩子的眼睛锁定在您的镜头上时，捕捉那些迷人的瞬间。对于最小的孩子，您可以让您的助手将他们放在椅子上，然后迅速走开，同时您准备好将手指放在快门按钮上。

在选择你的伴侣时，选择一个知道如何哄出那些微笑和咯咯笑声的人。它们会帮助您在拍摄自己的芒奇金时保持冷静，它们还会确保一切顺利得多。哥哥姐姐在这方面做得很好，父母也可以做得很好。

5. 从摆拍开始

并非每个儿童摄影会议都需要严格摆出姿势的镜头（坦率的图像也可以变得很棒！）。但是，如果您决定拍摄摆姿势的照片，最好从摆姿势最正式的照片开始。例如，在兄弟姐妹的镜头中，您希望每个人都面带灿烂的笑容直视镜头。

在会议开始时，您的小对象通常会更有耐心和合作。到最后，他们会变得有点焦躁和烦躁，这让他们更难静坐超过一两秒钟。

老实说，即使你从摆拍开始，也不能保证你会得到你想要的，但至少你有机会！

6.限制运动

孩子们有探索相机镜头无法触及的区域的本领。因此，如果您难以将它们固定在一个地方，请考虑使用椅子、凳子、沙发、篮子、秋千或其他任何能激发它们好奇心的道具来控制它们的移动。

这是一个绝妙的技巧：在完美时刻之前隐藏一把有趣的椅子。然后将它贴在您希望孩子所在的位置，看看他们的小雷达是否会直接引导他们到达那里。当他们自然而然地被吸引时，您可能会发现金子并感到高兴。请记住，他们可能根本不想坐在椅子上，但别担心！您可以适应并让他们在抓住它的同时站立，甚至让他们坐在附近的地面上。

灵活性是这里的关键——不要强迫它。从远处捕捉你的主题比最后拍摄一张红色、斑点、哭泣的脸的特写镜头要好得多。如果你觉得你的主题还没有准备好，你可以稍后再回到道具上。如果没有，就放手吧。您可能有很多想法，但最终只会使用其中的几个。

7. 让他们玩

一旦您拍摄了一些正式的照片（或者至少是孩子们坐着或站着的照片），就该退后一步让他们玩耍了！虽然您可以提供一些指导，但请避免过度摆姿势或试图让他们坐着不动。相信我，如果你太用力，你会发现自己陷入了一场你不会赢的战斗。

为什么不把剩下的时间集中在孩子们喜欢的活动上，或者向他们介绍一些可能激发他们兴奋的新事物呢？用洒水器把它们带到院子里，用​​滑梯去公园玩，或者开始海滩冒险来收集贝壳。来一场户外茶话会或放风筝怎么样？让他们在蹦床上蹦蹦跳跳，或者在草地上放一桶肥皂水。可能性是无止境！

哦，还有一个小秘密：音乐可以创造奇迹。考虑举办一场有趣的舞会，以获得灿烂的笑容。如果您一直在室内拍摄，那么在室外拍摄是个绝妙的主意。孩子们喜欢漫游和探索的空间，而宽敞的户外区域则开启了充满创意的世界。

8.尽量放松

拍摄儿童有时会让人不知所措，我理解。然而，花点时间深呼吸并找到平静感是至关重要的。

事情是这样的：孩子们有这种不可思议的能力来感受你的压力，这往往会导致他们做与你的目标完全相反的事情。所以尽你所能来释放那些神经。

如果您在第一次为客户拍摄之前感到紧张，为什么不和您自己或朋友的孩子一起练习呢？这是缓解拍摄前紧张情绪的好方法。让我分享一个缓解压力的秘方：像没有明天一样计划。在脑海中运行场景、创建详细的拍摄列表、侦察不同的位置，甚至练习调整相机设置。这种准备会增强您的信心，即使您最终在实际拍摄期间将您的计划扔到窗外。

儿童摄影技巧：最后的话

那是一个包装！通过迷人的儿童摄影领域，我们的狂野而美妙的旅程已经结束。有了这八个技巧，您现在就可以将那些珍贵的时刻永远定格。因此，准备好使用您的相机开始无数有趣的照片拍摄吧！

当您冒险进入儿童摄影世界时，请记住拥抱不完美之美并放下期望。 Start with poses, limit movement if needed, but above all, let them play and be their authentic selves. And most importantly, relax! The magic happens when you're in the moment, connecting with your subjects and capturing their world.

So embrace the unpredictable, cherish the fleeting moments, and have fun. Happy snapping!

If you're anything like me, you can't resist the electrifying atmosphere of a live concert. The roaring crowd, the pulsating beats, and those magical moments on stage that make your heart skip a beat – it's a photographer's paradise!

But let's face it: Capturing the energy and essence of a concert isn't so easy. From low-light conditions to fast-paced action, every gig presents its own unique challenges, and that's why it's essential to arm yourself with the right knowledge and techniques.

In this article, we'll delve into the nitty-gritty of photographing concerts and unlock plenty of secrets to capture those mind-blowing moments. I'll share the best gear and camera settings, explain how to anticipate the action, and reveal ways to navigate the chaotic dance of light and shadow. So grab some memory cards, make sure your camera batteries are charged, and get ready to rock the concert photography world!

1. Use a fast lens and shoot wide open

Using a fast lens (ie, a lens with a wide maximum aperture ) is crucial when it comes to concert photography. Most concerts take place in the evening or indoors with low lighting conditions, which means you need to allow as much light as possible through the lens to ensure a detailed exposure. Additionally, since performers are constantly moving on stage, you'll want to use faster shutter speeds to freeze their motion – and boosting the shutter speed without also widening the aperture will result in subpar results.

Good fast lenses include the 50mm f/1.8, 135mm f/1.8, and the 24-70mm f/2.8. These models are all offered by a variety of major camera manufacturers, and they do a great job of letting plenty of light into your camera.

Note that it's not enough to simply use a fast lens. You need to make sure you dial in the lens's widest aperture; that way, you can effectively capture sharp, well-exposed shots, assuming you also adjust your ISO (more on that in a later section!).

By the way, using a fast lens at its widest aperture can also create a beautiful shallow depth of field effect . This means that your main subject will be in sharp focus while the background fades into a soft blur, and it's a fantastic way to make your subject stand out and add a touch of artistic flair to your shots.

2. Shoot in Aperture Priority mode

Many beginners rely on Auto mode, but it often results in blurry or grainy photos without any control over camera settings. That's why I encourage you to choose Aperture Priority mode instead.

In Aperture Priority, you set the aperture you want while the camera automatically adjusts the shutter speed to match the changing lighting conditions. (Wondering about the ideal aperture? As mentioned earlier, go as wide as possible, like f/2.8 or even f/1.8, for sharp, well-exposed shots with stunning background bokeh .)

While some photographers advocate for Manual mode , I personally prefer Aperture Priority. By letting the camera handle the exposure, you can focus your mind on the artists, the crowd, and the overall atmosphere. It frees you up to capture those spontaneous and creative shots without getting bogged down in technical details.

3. Crank up the ISO

Concerts often unfold in dimly lit environments, and using a tripod just isn't an option for a whole host of reasons. So what can you do to ensure your shots come out sharp and well-exposed? Boost the one setting that gives you control in these challenging conditions: ISO.

Now, here's the deal with cranking up the ISO: It does introduce a bit of noise into your images. But in my experience, it's a tradeoff you have to make to capture those epic concert moments. Even if you have a fast lens with an ultra-wide aperture, it can only get you so far. That's why you need to rely on a higher ISO to push you the rest of the way.

Keep in mind that different cameras produce varying levels of noise based on their sensor quality. If you have the means, consider investing in a model with solid high-ISO capabilities. Then, before you head to your first concert photography gig, take a series of test shots at different ISO values. Pay attention to the point where the noise becomes too much for your liking. Remember that value and strive to stay below it whenever possible.

That said, a bit of noise can actually add a creative touch to your shots, especially if you're open to converting them to black and white. A monochrome image with noise can give off a cool film-grain feel, adding character to your work.

And if you happen to end up with a memory card full of ultra-noisy shots, don't fret too much; in post-processing, you can apply noise reduction to improve the image quality. However, keep in mind that noise-reduction algorithms do have their limitations, so it's best to get things right in the field as much as possible.

4. Avoid using your flash

When you're shooting at a concert, resist the temptation to whip out that flash. Imagine you're on stage, pouring your heart out, and suddenly you're blinded by a burst of light. Annoying, right? That's how performers feel, and you do not want to get on their bad side.

But it's not just about the artists. Part of concert photography is capturing the audience, too. You don't want to be that photographer who distracts everyone from the incredible show, so save your flash for another occasion.

And here's the thing: Even if you could use your flash, it wouldn't make much of a difference. The stage is usually too far away for the light to reach the subject. So why bother? Instead, focus on mastering the art of working with available light. Embrace the challenge of capturing the dimly lit atmosphere and the dynamic play of shadows. It'll result in much better photos!

5. Move around constantly

When it comes to concert photography, staying glued to one spot and snapping the same shot repeatedly just won't cut it. As a photographer, it's essential to keep on the move, flowing with the artists and following the ever-changing lighting dynamics. This way, you'll be able to capture those electrifying moments that truly stand out. Of course, remember to respect any venue or artist restrictions regarding movement.

If your view gets blocked by enthusiastic fans, quickly reposition yourself. (Whatever you do, don't ask them to move or get in their way. After all, they've paid to witness their favorite artists in action!) When the lead singer ventures to one side of the stage, it's your cue to hustle over there and capture the moment.

Bottom line: Moving around opens up a world of creative possibilities, allowing you to compose shots that are as diverse and vibrant as the music itself. So get your groove on, embrace the hustle, and capture the frenetic essence of the performance.

6. Wait and anticipate

Concerts are a whirlwind of action, but when it comes to concert photography, patience is key. It's all about playing the waiting game to capture those decisive moments that others might miss.

Now, I'm not saying you should spend your entire time waiting for a fleeting moment that may never come. No, it's about developing the skill to anticipate those golden opportunities. And the good news is that it's a skill that can be honed with practice and experience.

One effective way to improve your ability to predict good shots is to immerse yourself in the concert experience. Attend as many shows as you can and pay close attention. Notice patterns and recurring moments that unfold onstage. This could be a guitarist dramatically arching backward, a DJ energetically waving their arms, or a singer gripping the mic with passion. These are the moments that beg to be captured, and they tend to happen multiple times throughout a concert, giving you several opportunities to grab photos.

Another strategy is to observe the artists once the performance starts. Look for their unique habits and signature moves. By familiarizing yourself with their style, you can be prepared when those picture-perfect moments occur.

If you're truly dedicated to getting stellar shots and the artist has live videos available online, take advantage of them! Watch performances beforehand to give yourself a head start.

Remember, mastering the art of waiting and anticipating will elevate your concert photography game and ensure you don't miss a beat when it comes to capturing those stunning images.

Concert photography tips: final words

And that wraps up our epic journey through the wild world of concert photography! I've covered everything from nailing your camera settings to capturing set-defining moments, which means that you're ready to create some gorgeous concert shots of your own.

So remember the tips I've shared, and go forth and conquer the concert scene with your newfound knowledge and skills. Let your images tell the stories of epic performances, unforgettable melodies, and the soul-stirring power of music!

The HDR technique is a great way to capture well-exposed images of high dynamic range scenes.事实上，这是许多专业人士使用的方法，包括风景、旅游、房地产和建筑摄影师。

But the technique can be a bit tricky, and that's where this article comes in handy. Below, I explain everything you need to know to get started with HDR imaging, including:

  • What HDR photography is
  • Step-by-step instructions for taking HDR photos in the field
  • The best HDR software (both free and paid)
  • Tips and tricks for top-notch results

So if you're ready to unlock the full potential of this powerful approach, let's dive right in!

What is HDR photography?

HDR photography is a technique where multiple bracketed images are blended together to create a single beautifully exposed photo.

In other words, you capture several photos with different exposures , then combine them – in a program like Lightroom or Photoshop – to create a highly detailed file.

Why is this necessary?

Your camera can only capture a limited range of lights and darks (ie, it has a limited dynamic range ). If you point your camera at a dark mountain in front of a bright sunset, no matter how much you tweak the image exposure, your camera will generally fail to capture detail in the mountain and the sky; you'll either capture an image with a beautiful sky but a dark, detailless mountain, or you'll capture an image with a detailed mountain but a bright, blown-out sky.

High dynamic range photography aims to address this issue. Instead of relying on the camera's limited dynamic range capabilities, you take multiple photos that cover the entire tonal range of the scene.

Then you combine the detailed sections of each photo and finish with a file full of well-exposed shadows, midtones, and highlights.

In the case of the mountain at sunset, you could take three images:

  • A darker image to capture detail in the sky
  • A brighter image to capture detail in the mountain
  • A “standard” image to capture detail in the midtones

Then you could blend the three files, using the sky from dark image, the mountain from the bright image, and the midtones from the middle image.

When should you use the HDR approach?

Most scenes don't require HDR techniques. Cameras have limited dynamic range capabilities, sure, but they're still capable of handling most standard situations; in other words, you don't need to do high-dynamic range photography all the time.

And HDR techniques come with significant limitations. To use the HDR process, you need to take at least two “starter” images, and neither the scene nor the camera can shift from shot to shot. You should (almost) always use a tripod, and you should aim to capture stationary scenes with little-to-no movement.

Therefore, I don't recommend HDR photography when shooting action, such as sports, wildlife, birds, or even portraits; your subjects will move frequently, and you'll struggle to get two bracketed images that can be effectively blended together.

On the other hand, HDR techniques are great for landscape photography, real estate photography, architectural photography, and cityscape photography. These genres allow for slow, tripod-based shooting, and the scenes feature limited movement, too.

More specifically, you should use HDR photography when you encounter stationary scenes with very light and very dark tones. Here are a few common scenarios where HDR techniques can be a big help:

  • Sunrise and sunset landscape and cityscape scenes (with a bright sky and a dark foreground)
  • Real-estate and architectural interior scenes (with bright windows and/or artificial lighting)
  • Twilight and night scenes (with artificial lighting and deep shadows)
  • Landscape scenes with a mix of bright light and shade

Of course, it's impossible to say for sure whether a scene will benefit from an HDR treatment, and camera sensors are steadily getting better at handling high dynamic range scenes. But when in doubt, you can always shoot a few bracketed exposures; that way, when you arrive home, you can decide whether you captured enough detail in one of your shots or whether you need to blend the files together.

A key problem: avoiding the HDR look

While HDR photography is a perfectly legitimate technique frequently used by professionals, it has unfortunately gained a negative reputation in many photography circles. When HDR first became popular, photographers often utilized the technique in an obvious and over-the-top manner. The resulting images appeared extremely unnatural, with grungy tones, excessive contrast, and an abundance of detail in the highlights and shadows. To make matters worse, these photos sometimes featured unpleasant artifacts such as halos and noise.

This tarnished the reputation of HDR photography as a whole. However, it's crucial to recognize that there are many flavors of HDR editing, and it is very possible to use HDR processes to create images that accurately reflect what your eyes saw when you originally captured the shot.

Yes, it's important not to take your HDR editing too far, but the good news is that modern post-processing programs excel at producing natural and realistic-looking results. Keep this in mind as you embark on your HDR editing journey, and you can easily avoid the pitfalls of the “bad HDR” look.

How to do HDR photography: step by step

In this section, I offer clear, step-by-step instructions for creating an HDR image, including both file capture and processing.

Step 1: Set up your camera

As I emphasized above, it's important to keep your camera steady when shooting HDR, so if you're planning to use HDR techniques, make sure you own a decent tripod.

Once you find a scene that could benefit from a high dynamic range treatment, mount your camera on your tripod and determine your composition (the way you would when capturing a normal, non-HDR shot).

Then select your camera settings. First, adjust your camera mode to Manual ; you don't want the exposure changing from shot to shot.

Set your ISO at its lowest value to prevent noise , and choose an aperture that gets you your desired depth of field (I often shoot at f/8 to f/11, but you can go wider or narrower depending on your goals). Choose a shutter speed that gives you a balanced exposure (that is, make sure you expose for the midtones, not the highlights or the shadows). Here, it can help to look at your camera's exposure bar, which is generally visible at the bottom of the viewfinder.

Switch your lens over to manual focus – you don't want the point of focus changing between shots! – and adjust the focus ring until you get the result that you're after.

Step 2: Take a “correctly” exposed image

Once you've set up your shot, take one last look at your camera settings. If your shutter speed is below 1/60s or so, make sure you use your camera's two-second timer or a remote release to prevent camera shake.

Finally, take your first shot. Review the results on the back of your LCD. The midtones should be well exposed, while the highlights and shadows are much less important.

If your image is very dark or very bright (ie, exposed for the highlights or the shadows, respectively), I'd recommend adjusting your shutter speed and reshooting. Once you've successfully captured a file with detailed midtones, move on to the next step:

Step 3: Take an overexposed and an underexposed image

Keep your ISO, aperture, and point of focus consistent. Then reduce your shutter speed by a stop or two and take a photo.

The result should look overexposed, but the darker portions of the scene should feature plenty of detail. (You can check this on your LCD or your camera's histogram .)

Next, raise your shutter speed several stops, then take a photo. This time, you should get an underexposed image, one that is missing lots of shadow detail but that accurately exposes the brightest parts of the scene.

Step 4: Consider the results (and take more photos if necessary)

At this point, you should have three photos: a standard (midtone) image, an overexposed image, and an underexposed image.

In many cases, this will be enough for a nice HDR blend, but if your scene features an extremely high dynamic range, you may want to shoot five photos, seven photos, or even nine photos. Simply keep adjusting the shutter speed for increasingly lighter and darker photos until you're satisfied with your results.

Over time, you'll get a sense of the number of shots you need to create a good HDR file, but I always recommend you review your images – and their corresponding histograms – on your LCD. If you find that you've captured sufficient detail across your sequence of photos, you can move on to the next step:

Step 5: Blend the files together

After an HDR shoot, you'll need to blend the files together for a well-exposed composite image. The specifics will depend on your choice of post-processing software, but most programs make it pretty easy to create good-looking HDRs. Here's how to create an HDR blend in Lightroom :

First, import your photos. Select all the files you need to blend together, then right-click and choose Photo>;Photo Merge>;HDR .

An HDR window will appear. I'd recommend checking the Auto Align box, especially if you shot handheld or your tripod moved from shot to shot. You can also check the Auto Settings box.

If your scene had moving elements (such as blowing branches or people walking), select the Medium or High deghosting option.

Finally, hit Merge , and wait while Lightroom processes your image! It might take a few seconds (or minutes, depending on your computer and the number of images you tried to blend), but you should soon see an HDR file appear.

Step 6: Enhance your HDR file

At this point, you have a high dynamic range file, but what should you do with it?

One option is to simply export it as a JPEG for sharing online, but I'd really recommend you first apply some additional post-processing. Tweak the exposure, the shadows, and the highlights; add (or subtract) contrast; add saturation and play around with color grading; and sharpen the shot as required. Then export it as a JPEG for viewing.

The best HDR software

If you're serious about bringing out the full potential of your HDR images, using the right processing program is crucial. While I've explained how to process bracketed files in Lightroom as an example, there are several other fantastic options to consider.

For instance, Capture One, ON1 Photo RAW, and Photoshop are all comprehensive editing programs that include HDR blending capabilities alongside their normal features. The advantage of these programs is that you can incorporate the HDR merge into your standard workflow without needing to rely on a second editor, but the disadvantage is that they offer somewhat limited control over the blending process.

If you want more control, consider downloading a dedicated HDR program. Photomatix and HDR Efex are two prominent examples that offer advanced features specifically for HDR editing. With these programs, you can dive deeper into adjusting tones, merging exposures, and achieving the look you're after.

While most HDR software comes at a cost, there are a few free options available, as well. Luminance HDR offers a range of features and is a great option for those who want to explore HDR photography without committing to a paid program.

At the end of the day, selecting the right HDR program largely depends on your personal preferences, workflow, editing goals, and budget. Experimenting with different options can help you find the one that resonates with your style and allows you to unleash your creative vision.

HDR camera modes

Some cameras offer dedicated HDR shooting modes. That way, you don't have to do any manual bracketing or blending – you can set your camera to its HDR mode, press the shutter button, and end up with a fully merged HDR shot.

But before you jump on board, let me explain the pros and cons of relying on your camera's HDR mode.

First, let's talk about convenience. HDR camera modes can save you time and effort by automating the entire process. Gone are the days of meticulously capturing multiple shots and spending extra time blending them together during post-processing. With a simple click, you can capture a bracketed sequence, and the camera does the rest.

However, convenience often comes at a price, and HDR camera modes are no exception. One of the major drawbacks is the limited control over the process. While this varies depending on your camera model, you may find yourself unable to choose the number of bracketed shots, modify the bracketing intervals, or determine how the images are blended. This lack of control can be frustrating, especially for photographers who prefer a hands-on approach.

Another potential downside is the file format. Many cameras that offer HDR modes only create JPEG HDR files. While JPEGs are convenient and widely compatible, they lack the editing flexibility of RAW files. If you want to create the best possible results, I highly recommend working in RAW.

Considering these limitations, I generally advocate for manual HDR photography. Although it requires more effort, it grants you unparalleled control over the outcome. By manually capturing and blending your bracketed shots, you can carefully adjust each step of the process to achieve the desired result. The extra work is well worth the artistic freedom and control it provides!

Tips for creating breathtaking HDR images

Now that you're familiar with the basics, let's explore a few tips and tricks to elevate your HDR photos:

1. Choose your compositions carefully

您可能已经意识到，创建 HDR 图像比拍摄标准照片需要更多的努力。 It involves capturing multiple files and blending them together during post-processing. To make the most of your time and energy, it's crucial to be deliberate in your shooting approach.

While it may be tempting to go trigger-happy and capture dozens of bracketed shots from every angle, I urge you to exercise restraint. Overloading yourself with excessive files will only lead to a daunting and time-consuming post-processing phase. Quality over quantity is the mantra here!

So instead of capturing HDR shots left and right, take a moment to pause and think about each scene. Work on identifying a single good composition, refining it, then capturing one sequence of bracketed files that you then blend together.

Of course, there may be instances when you find yourself torn between two slightly different compositions. In such cases, capturing multiple versions can be a good idea. However, strike a balance and avoid going overboard. The key is to maintain restraint in your shooting so that each shot is purposeful and intentional.

2. Explore manual exposure blending

If you merge together your HDR shots using an automated process (like I did in my Lightroom example), the result is usually good. But it'll occasionally look disappointing, or it'll be decent but not up to your standards. That's when you should consider delving into the world of manual exposure blending – a technique that allows you to craft stunning HDR images through careful fine-tuning and adjustment.

Manual exposure blending may sound intimidating, but it opens up a realm of possibilities and gives you the power to create truly exceptional results. By utilizing a process known as luminosity masking, you can blend different parts of each image based on their unique light and dark values. This level of precision empowers you to elevate your results like never before.

Now, I'll say it upfront: Manual exposure blending isn't a walk in the park. It requires some effort and has a real learning curve. However, if you do a lot of HDR shooting, it's worth the effort. You probably won't need it all the time, but it's great to have in your back pocket for those times when your editing program struggles to create a nice blend.

3. Don't be afraid of handheld HDR

While I've stressed the importance of using a tripod for capturing bracketed shots, I want to let you in on a little secret: It's possible to achieve stunning handheld HDR images.

You simply need to capture your bracketed shots while keeping your camera as steady as possible. It helps to brace yourself against a solid object, like the ground, a car, or a tree, to minimize any camera movement.

Once you've captured your handheld photos, it's time to bring them into your processing program. The good news is that most modern software is equipped with powerful algorithms that can align and merge the elements in each image, compensating for any slight movements you might have made.

However, it's important to be aware that there are some trade-offs to consider. The more your camera moves between shots, the greater the chance of losing pixels around the edges of the frame because the program may need to crop in for alignment purposes. So it's best to be as stable as possible during the handheld shooting process.

While shooting HDR images with a tripod is generally the superior option, there are times when circumstances prevent you from using one. In those situations, don't hesitate to try the handheld approach. You might be surprised by the results!

HDR photography: final words

Congratulations – you've made it to the end of our ultimate guide to HDR photography! Now that you know how to use this powerful technique, it's time to unleash your creativity and take your images to a whole new level.

Remember, HDR photography isn't just about merging exposures and adjusting sliders. It's an art form that requires careful composition, thoughtful shooting, and skillful post-processing. Make sure you work hard, push the boundaries, and see what you can produce.

So head out with your camera. Practice your bracketing. And create some HDR magic!

HDR Imaging FAQ

What does “HDR” stand for in photography?

“HDR” stands for “high dynamic range.” It's a technique that involves capturing and blending multiple exposures of the same scene to achieve a wider range of tonal details, from the darkest shadows to the brightest highlights. The result is an image that more closely resembles what the human eye can perceive in terms of dynamic range.

Should you always use HDR imaging?

While HDR imaging can produce stunning results, it's not necessary to use it for every photograph. HDR is particularly beneficial in high-contrast scenes where the camera struggles to capture details in both the shadows and highlights. So it's best to assess each scene individually and decide if HDR is the right technique to achieve your desired outcome.

Do professional photographers use HDR?

Absolutely! Professional photographers often utilize HDR techniques to capture and convey the full dynamic range of a scene in their images. However, it's important to note that professionals use HDR judiciously and generally aim for natural-looking results, avoiding the exaggerated and over-processed look that has given HDR a bad reputation in some circles.

Is RAW or JPEG better for HDR?

RAW files provide greater flexibility and control during post-processing. For instance, RAW files retain more tonal data, allowing you to recover details in both the shadows and highlights more effectively. However, some cameras offer HDR modes that create JPEG HDR photos. While this can be convenient, shooting in RAW gives you more latitude for adjustments and enhancements in the editing process.

Is HDR good for portraits?

HDR isn't typically the go-to technique for portraiture. However, there can be exceptions to this, such as when shooting environmental portraits with a wide dynamic range or when incorporating HDR as a creative choice for a specific portrait style.

What software is best for processing HDR files?

在本文中，我们将探讨 50mm 焦距的威力。首先，您会发现为什么在拍摄风景时使用 50 毫米玻璃是个好主意，然后我将分享可帮助您提升效果的技巧和技巧。如果您正在努力选择合适的 50mm 镜头，我将提供一些购买建议来帮助您。

因此，准备好进入 50 毫米风景摄影的迷人领域吧。让我们开始吧！

使用 50mm 镜头拍摄风景的原因

50 毫米镜头（也称为nifty fifty ）对于风景摄影师初学者来说是一个了不起的选择，对于更有经验的摄影师来说也是很棒的选择。在本节中，我将解释原因 - 我希望让您相信使用 50mm 镜头拍摄风景是一个绝妙的主意！

1. 50mm 镜头帮助您专注于重要的事情

50mm 的焦距更紧——当然不是广角！ – 我们倾向于将风景视为在一帧中包含许多元素的庞大场景。

但是所有风景都需要广角视角吗？我们不能在更紧凑的包装中捕捉我们周围地区的美丽吗？我想是这样。例如，一个以连绵起伏的丘陵和一棵有趣的树为特色的户外场景足以创造出发人深省的图像，而无需求助于一览无余的风景构图。

以 50 毫米拍摄风景会迫使您专注于场景中最重要的部分。您可能想在一次拍摄中捕捉一切——树木、岩石、前景、背景——但在 50mm 时，这是不可能做到的，但这是一件好事。

随着时间的推移，50 毫米镜头会训练您识别重要的东西。你会开始本能地从你的场景中排除不重要的元素。

2. 50mm 定焦提供出色的图像质量

最好的风景摄影镜头从一个角落到另一个角落都很锋利。毕竟，风景摄影甚至可以突出最小的细节——秋天树叶的纹理、海滩上的沙子漩涡——所以最大化分辨率是值得的。

幸运的是，50 毫米的定焦镜头非常锐利，尤其是在成本方面。在我看来，它们提供了当今市场上所有镜头中性价比最高的清晰度。

当然，它们在全开时并不是完美的，但光圈缩小到 f/5.6 左右时，图像质量还是很不错的。更窄的光圈（无论如何，您可能会在此处拍摄大部分风景图像）仍然会产生出色的效果。

许多风景摄影初学者都使用套装镜头。虽然这些镜头工作正常并且肯定可以为您提供一些美丽的图像，但清晰度与 50mm 镜头不在同一水平。

3. 50mm 素数迫使您慢慢来

由于 50mm 是定焦镜头，您将获得额外的好处：单一焦距意味着您不能随处拍摄。相反，您需要四处走动以找到最佳角度和距离。这会自动迫使你考虑你的投篮，这总是一件好事。

使用变焦，您可能会不假思索地调整焦距，直到场景以看起来不错的方式构图。但是，虽然您最终可能会拍出不错的照片，但漂亮的 50 张照片会让您有动力去尝试不同的东西，无论是新的角度、不同的距离还是不寻常的视角。

事实上，如果您愿意的话，我建议您将这个思考过程变成一个仔细的例行程序。一旦您看到一个有趣的主题，就拿出您值得信赖的 50 毫米定焦相机。然后将取景器对准您的眼睛并行走。只需在场景周围来回走动，直到您从多个方向对其进行测试。当你在做的时候，保持低位，甚至尝试找到一个高点。

你会带着更好的形象回家（或两个，或三个）。在这个过程中，你会成为一名更好的摄影师，因为你被迫深入思考视角、构图和焦距。

4.如果你真的想拍广角场景

在前面的部分中，我强调了隔离单个主题并更加紧密的价值。我坚持我所说的，因为 50mm是拍摄更私密风景的理想焦距。

但是，如果您遇到一个急需广角视野的场景，那么一切都不会丢失。因为您实际上可以使用50mm 镜头和一点创意全景拼接来创建广角图像。

你看，虽然 50mm 不是广角焦距，但通过拍摄几张 50mm 的照片并慢慢旋转相机，你可以创建一个全景图——然后可以在 Photoshop 中将其拼接成广角图像。

事实上，一幅漂亮的 50 幅风景全景图可能看起来比一张广角照片更具戏剧性！

5. 50mm 镜头非常轻巧紧凑

如果您对风景摄影很认真，那么您可能已经拖着相当多的装备到处走。 相机机身，其他镜头（你不会只带一个镜头出门吧？）， 三脚架；清单还在继续。

当你外出时，你最不需要的就是更重的镜头，对吧？但是您知道佳能 50mm f/1.8 的重量仅为 4.6 盎司（即 130 克）吗？它也非常小，所以它几乎不占用您相机包中的任何空间（如果您愿意，您可以将它放在口袋里随身携带）。

对于许多摄影师来说，轻便的镜头带来了自由。拿起相机背包出门不再是件苦差事。而且您可以手持轻便的设置而不会感到疲倦，这总是一个好处。

50mm风景照片技巧

致力于使用 50mm 镜头拍摄风景，但不确定如何改善拍摄效果？在本节中，我将提供获得迷人结果的最佳技巧和技巧！

1.使用大光圈

风景摄影师通常几乎只使用窄光圈拍摄，以便以清晰的焦点捕捉整个场景。但是 50 毫米镜头提供非常宽的最大光圈，例如 f/1.8 和 f/1.4，您可以使用它们来改变风景照片。

拥抱 50mm 镜头的大光圈功能打开了一个充满可能性的世界。通过使用更大的光圈，您可以释放背景模糊的美感。这种迷人的效果有助于将注意力吸引到您的主题上，将其与背景分开，并为您的照片注入深度感和艺术感。

为了充分利用大光圈方法，我建议在您的风景中确定一个清晰的焦点 - 即吸引观众的主题。它可以是一棵孤零零的树，可以是汹涌的海浪，也可以是一朵娇嫩的花。然后，通过将自己定位在相对靠近拍摄对象的位置并拨入大光圈，您可以创建梦幻般的绘画背景，使您的图像有别于传统的风景摄影。

但是请注意，发挥大光圈的力量需要精确和技巧。在浅景深的情况下，实现清晰聚焦的窗口变得更小。花时间仔细关注您选择的主题是至关重要的。不要害怕根据需要尝试不同的焦点。

2.注意你的景深

在之前的技巧中，我谈到了使用大光圈来创建浅景深效果。然而，即使您打算拍摄始终清晰的图像，您也需要非常注意景深。

为什么？焦距越长，景深就会越窄。而且由于 50mm 镜头比传统的景观玻璃长得多，景深会明显变窄（其他条件相同）。

保持整个镜头从前到后的清晰仍然是很有可能的，但是您需要比其他情况下使用的光圈更窄，并且您可能还需要在超焦距处仔细对焦。 （它可以帮助使用超焦距计算器，您可以在PhotoPills等摄影应用程序中找到它。）

顺便说一下，如果您正在努力让所有东西都对焦，为了安全起见，不要害怕拍摄几张焦点略有不同的照片。您还可以使用焦点堆叠技术，将焦点包围起来，然后在后期处理中将生成的图像混合在一起。

3.寻找图案和几何形状

虽然广角镜头非常适合捕捉广阔的场景和一览无余的远景，但您值得信赖的 50mm 镜头可以让您专注于风景中的特定元素。使用 50 毫米焦距，您可以将有趣的主题归零，并采用更抽象的方法来构图。

因此，我鼓励您转变视角，开始从形状、线条和重复的角度思考，而不是仅仅将风景视为物体的集合。在景观元素中寻找对称、和谐和韵律的有趣区域。

我知道这听起来有点挑战，但请相信我：很快，它就会成为第二天性。另外，如果您的第一次尝试没有立即产生令人兴奋的结果，请不要气馁。像任何技能一样，它需要练习和敏锐的眼光才能发展。坚持下去，你会见证快速的进步。

图案和几何的伟大之处在于它们无处不在。从树枝的错综复杂的线条到拍打海岸的有节奏的海浪，有无穷无尽的视觉魔力等待捕捉。因此，下次您在大自然中时，请留意那些隐藏的构图！

4. 拍摄亲密的风景照

您可能会想，“等一下，风景摄影不就是广袤无垠的远景吗？”但是，尽管这些广阔的场景无疑令人着迷，但如果您知道该怎么做，还有整个美丽的世界等待您去捕捉。

你看，50mm 镜头往往提供非常令人印象深刻的特写功能。它们没有真正的微距放大倍率，但您可以靠得足够近来记录各种令人叹为观止的小细节，并且您可以利用这种能力创造出非常亲密的图像。

例如，您可以拍摄森林地面上以秋叶为特色的小场景，或草原上花朵和草地的微型静物照片。这些镜头通常感觉非常有意义，可以很好地真正传达风景的本质。

50mm 焦距特别适合私密风景拍摄的原因在于它能够复制您的眼睛所见。它以一种感觉自然的方式捕捉场景，展示复杂的细节，就像现实生活中的观众所感知的那样。

那么，您如何开始探索 50 毫米风景摄影的这一迷人方面呢？很简单：与周围的世界亲密接触。开始俯视森林地面，然后停下来检查周围的环境。寻找那些经常被忽视但具有巨大美感和意义的小元素。

如果您还没有测试过 50mm 镜头的特写功能，现在就是最佳时机！花一些时间探索最大放大倍率的世界，看看你能创造什么！

5.观看背景

不同的镜头会导致摄影师以不同的方式思考。广角镜头具有广阔的视野，往往会让您思考整个场景及其中的一切。但是 50mm 镜头往往会鼓励您根据特定主题进行思考：树木、山脉、湖泊、草地等。

这不是一件坏事——事实上，它可以成为捕捉独特镜头的好方法。然而，它有时确实会带来重大后果：它会迫使您专注于主题而忽略其背后的背景。

然而，背景是每张风景照片的重要组成部分，在构图时仔细考虑背景是至关重要的。您希望它与前景和中景相得益彰，而不是分散注意力。

拍摄时，问问自己：背景是否补充和增强了我拍摄的情绪和叙事？或者它是否分散了主要焦点？如果您发现任何干扰因素或不太有效的因素，只需进行一些调整即可。四处走动，改变你的视角，或找到不同的有利位置，以确保更令人愉悦的背景。有时，向旁边走几步或靠近你的拍摄对象会产生不同的效果。

不要害怕尝试并花时间找到完美的背景。请记住，耐心是风景摄影的关键。通过在深思熟虑的背景下投入一点额外的努力，您可以将您的图像从优秀提升到令人叹为观止。

6. 随时随地拍摄风景照片

作为风景摄影师，您知道捕捉大自然中那些神奇的瞬间通常需要在正确的时间出现在正确的地点。有时，这些机会会在您最意想不到的时候出现。这就是 50 毫米镜头的紧凑尺寸带来如此大不同的地方 - 它为您提供了灵活性，无论您身在何处，都可以为那些转瞬即逝的瞬间做好准备。

具体来说，我鼓励您找一台轻便的相机，在上面安装您的 50mm 镜头，然后随身携带。这样，如果您开车去上班，而挡风玻璃外的世界变成了令人叹为观止的场景，您可以靠边停车并捕捉它——这要归功于您的便携式 50 毫米风景设置。 （如果您打算经常停下来，最好早点离开，这样您就可以毫无压力地拍照！）

当然，您不一定要开车才能找到好的摄影机会。大自然无处不在，即使在大多数城市地区也是如此！因此，当您进行日常工作时，请留意非凡的光线和迷人的构图。当您发现那个完美的时刻时，您只需停下来，深吸一口气，让您的 50mm 镜头发挥它的魔力。

如果您确实一直随身携带景观装备，请采取措施确保其安全。如果您打算将它放在车内，请将它存放在看不见的地方，并确保在您四处走动时它不会暴露在恶劣环境中（我建议投资购买一个好的防水相机包）。

The best 50mm lenses for landscape photography

如果您正在寻找高质量的 50mm 镜头来拍摄风景，我很高兴地说您的选择太多了；几乎每个相机制造商都提供一个（通常更多）50mm 范围内的出色镜头。这些镜头往往拥有出色的光学性能和宽大的最大光圈，而且它们的价格也非常便宜。

以下是一些按相机类型和制造商分类的快速建议：

如果您是佳能 DSLR 摄影师，请查看EF 50mm f/1.8 STM ，它可能是有史以来性价比最高的镜头，而且无疑是一款出色的 50mm 风景镜头。 More serious shooters might consider the EF 50mm f/1.4 USM for its slightly wider aperture.佳能无反光镜用户应该购买RF 50mm f/1.8 STM ，尽管计划将镜头用于非风景用途的专业人士可能希望购买（非常昂贵的） RF 50mm f/1.2L USM 。

尼康 DSLR 摄影师应该购买锐利且价格合理的AF-S 50mm f/1.8G ，或者价格更高但散景出色的AF-S 50mm f/1.4G 。 Z 卡口摄影师可以购买Z 50mm f/1.8 S ；它比您对 50mm 镜头的预期要贵，但质量非常好。尼康确实销售Z 50mm f/1.2 S ，但与佳能同类产品一样，它并不便宜。

最后，索尼射手应该检查一下FE 50mm f/1.8 镜头、 FE 50mm f/1.4 GM 镜头和FE 50mm f/1.2 GM 镜头。 f/1.8 版本是同类产品中最轻的，也是最便宜的 - 因此除非您计划在风景作品之外拍摄人像或事件，否则它可能是最佳选择。

50mm风景摄影：最后的话

所有镜头和焦距都有优点和缺点，当然可以使用更宽的玻璃制作外壳。但是 50mm 定焦镜头是风景摄影的绝佳选择，尤其是如果您是初学者；它将使您对照片有不同的看法，它将使您摆脱繁重设置的束缚，并为您提供清晰锐利的图像。

想要提升您的会议摄影水平？你来对地方了。

我们整理了一大堆技巧，可让您将会议照片拍得更上一层楼。从确保您配备合适的装备到捕捉那些坦率、真实的时刻的技巧，我们都能满足您的需求。

会议摄影不仅仅是创造记录照片；它是关于捕捉知识交流的本质、网络的快感以及在这些充满活力的环境中展开的故事。因此，加入我们吧，我们将揭示使您能够创建具有视觉吸引力和影响力的图像的技术。准备好以前所未有的方式让那些非凡的会议时刻永垂不朽！

1. 带上额外的电池、存储卡、数据线和充电器

这听起来似乎很容易，但您会惊讶地发现有多少人在一天中途发现自己陷入困境，拼命寻找备用电池，尤其是在事情刚刚升温的时候。所以帮自己一个忙，至少多带一套电池。

Remember, if you're using a DSLR or a mirrorless camera , you can't just pop into the nearest corner store to grab a battery replacement.我建议投资一块（或两块）备用电池。 At the very least, make sure you bring your charger!

至于存储卡，我不了解你，但大多数人不会在会议期间填写存储卡。尽管如此，随身携带一些备份总不会有坏处。您永远不知道卡何时会丢失或停止工作。您可能还想带上读卡器！

我们不要忘记电缆。似乎在我参加的每次会议上，我最终都会把我的电缆借给不同的与会者。人们似乎总是把电缆留在家里，但如果您想成功地传输和存储照片，手边备有相关电缆是个不错的主意。

在我值得信赖的装备包中，我总是有相机的备用电池以及充电器和数据线。这些物品永远不会离开我的包，确保它们在我需要时总是触手可及。哦，还有我的备用存储卡？它牢固地固定在我的相机背带上，所以我永远不必疯狂地寻找它。

2. 退出自动模式

我收到的关于使用傻瓜相机的最佳建议之一是摆脱自动模式的束缚。你为什么问？因为它赋予您更多控制权。离开自动模式后，您可以调整白平衡、调整 ISO，有时甚至可以调整光圈和快门速度。

当您依赖自动模式时，您的照片往往具有那种通用的假期快照氛围。你知道那个：明亮的闪光，一切都在焦点上，带有一丝颗粒感。

您应该改用哪种模式？请允许我向您介绍光圈优先模式。它可以让您独立微调光圈和 ISO，以便确定图像曝光。或者， 快门优先模式也可以派上用场，尤其是在捕捉动感十足的瞬间时。它让您可以控制快门速度，让您可以根据需要冻结或模糊运动。

我知道深入研究这些模式可能会让人感到有点害怕，但相信我，这是值得的。在下次会议之前花点时间练习。 That way, when the big day arrives, you'll be well-prepared to seize the perfect shots.

3. 不引人注目

当我在会议的镜头后面时，我的任务是无缝融入。我不想引起注意或被注意。相反，我的目标是捕捉人们最真实的时刻——全神贯注于演讲中，露出真诚的笑容，或者只是沉浸在会议体验中。我避开精心设计的姿势，因为 90% 的时间人们更喜欢自拍。那些自然、轻松、真实的图像讲述了一个强有力的故事。

现在，成为隔离墙的一部分并不意味着成为跟踪狂或像狗仔队一样行事。这是关于保持尊重的距离并观看场景有机地展开。捕捉那些转瞬即逝的瞬间的秘诀在于在场，而不是制造它们。

为实现这一点，使用较小的相机和镜头等不显眼的设备是有利的。此外，如果您的相机提供静音拍摄模式，我强烈建议您使用它。现代无反光镜相机具有真正静音的拍摄模式，消除了被摄对象无意中听到快门并感到难为情的风险。

4.注意背景

在许多方面，背景与主要主题本身一样重要。事实上，它可以成就或破坏一个伟大的镜头。

您绝对不希望在您的照片中从人们的头顶冒出树木或灯柱等随机物体。它看起来不专业，并且会阻止观众关注重要的事情：会议主持人和与会者。

因此，在按下快门按钮之前，请快速浏览一下背景。是否有任何奇怪或分散注意力的元素悄悄进入？如果是这样，请暂停片刻并重新构图。

如果您发现自己身处拥挤的区域，请尝试靠近您的拍摄对象并使用更大的光圈（例如 f/2.8）来营造可爱的背景虚化效果。这种技术将有助于最大程度地减少任何分散注意力的元素，让您的主题真正闪耀。

5.尽量不要使用闪光灯

在会议上拍摄精美的照片可能是一项相当大的挑战。大多数时候，照明效果不尽如人意，诱使您使用闪光灯拍摄更明亮的照片。然而，使用机载闪光灯往往弊大于利。它使纹理变平，使您的图像失去深度，并且可以给人一种不讨人喜欢的头灯下的鹿的外观。

与其使用闪光灯，不如考虑使用其他方法来获得光线充足的照片。一种选择是扩大光圈，让更多光线进入镜头。另一种技术是提高ISO ，这会增加相机对光线的敏感度。 （不过要小心，因为将 ISO 推得太高会给你的照片带来难看的噪点。值得庆幸的是，现代相机擅长处理高 ISO，通常可以在 ISO 3200 及更高的 ISO 下拍摄而不会出现明显的噪点。）

此外，请留意享受自然光或强烈人工照明的会议区域。将自己放在靠近窗户或靠近强光源的位置，以利用可用的照明条件。

6.注意灯光

摄影，无论是捕捉令人叹为观止的风景还是记录会议，都围绕着一个关键元素：光。必须注意光线（无论是太阳的自然光还是人工照明）如何与您的拍摄对象相互作用。

当你第一次进入每个新会议室时，花点时间观察一下现场。前面是否沐浴在透过窗户射进来的灿烂阳光中？有亮区和暗区吗？也许场地缺乏自然光，完全依靠人工光源？

这些照明情况可能看起来令人生畏，但不要害怕。将它们视为释放您的创造力的机会。例如，逆光照片中的主体在光线下形成轮廓，具有迷人的魅力。此外，玩弄光影的相互作用开辟了各种摄影风格。

请记住，关键是要适应并充分利用可用光线来制作令人惊叹的图像。让您的技能大放异彩，捕捉展现在您面前的美丽！

7. 以 RAW 格式拍摄

在拍摄令人惊叹的会议照片时，这里有一个专业提示： 以 RAW 格式拍摄。虽然 JPEG 可能看起来不错并且很容易在线共享，但它们实际上会删除重要数据，这些数据可能会在以后增强您的照片。

另一方面，RAW 文件保留了相机捕获的所有信息。这意味着您将在后期处理中拥有更大的灵活性，使您能够进行精确调整并展现出图像中的最佳效果——这是我强烈推荐的步骤。

当我说将相机切换到 RAW 会改变游戏规则时，我并不夸张。它使您能够挽救包含极亮和极暗区域的文件中曝光过度或曝光不足的像素。如果您在 RAW 中工作，就可以告别错过完美拍摄的机会！

此外，使用 RAW 文件使色彩校正变得轻而易举，甚至为那些寻求更具艺术感的人开辟了电影色彩分级的可能性。

8.拍很多照片

人们经常问我，“你是如何拍出如此惊人的照片的？”好吧，我会告诉你一个小秘密：这是运气和主动快门手指的结合。当我第一次接触到数码单反相机时，有人告诉我每次构图至少拍三张照片，这是一个很好的建议。

为什么？因为人们往往会眨眼、移开视线并做出各种不可预测的事情。通过快速连续拍摄，您可以显着增加捕捉到您想要的构图的机会。

顺便说一句，这就是连拍模式派上用场的地方。将相机设置为连拍模式，当您按住快门按钮时，它会快速连续拍摄一系列照片。

但是不要太过分了。虽然拍摄多张照片很重要，但拍摄的次数越多，以后需要筛选的次数就越多，这真的很痛苦。在捕获太少和捕获太多之间找到适当的平衡。

9. 少变焦，多走路

他们说变焦镜头让摄影师变懒了。我对此不确定，但事情是这样的：当你四处走动、靠近并尝试不同的角度时，你通常会拍到更好的照片。

就个人而言，我的大部分会议照片都依赖 85mm f/1.8 定焦镜头，这意味着没有变焦。如果我想要一些东西来填充更多的画面，我必须走得更近一些。你知道吗？在进行构图调整时，我有时会偶然发现一些意想不到的方法，使画面更加迷人。

现在，请不要误会我的意思——我并不是建议您完全放弃变焦镜头。我有一个值得信赖的 70-200mm f/2.8 镜头，专门用于会议（它在低光条件下表现非常出色），当我无法靠近时，它可以让我放大扬声器。但是，只要有可能，我都会尝试通过身体而不是镜头进行调整。

10.玩得开心

会议摄影可能是快节奏、高压时刻的旋风。但在所有挑战中，也有机会获得极大的乐趣。你只需要愿意抓住它！

即使您因拍摄活动而获得报酬，也请记住为您的工作注入一些乐趣。 Seek out those humorous shots that bring a smile to your face, and don't shy away from exploring your artistic side.为自己留出一些时间。

如果拍摄确实开始感觉像是一件苦差事，除非您正在上班，否则请尝试将相机放在一边并专注于体验！

11. 不要沉迷于装备

当然，我有一流的专业设备，可以用来为客户拍照，但你知道吗？我可信赖的傻瓜相机仍然功能强大！

拥有大量耗尽钱包的设备并不会自动让您成为摄影大师。相反，您可以使用塑料玩具相机创造奇迹。请记住，相机只是工具，所以没有必要比那些炫耀比蹒跚学步的孩子大的镜头的人低人一等。真正的秘诀在于你的射击能力、玩乐能力和不断尝试的能力。

因此，放松对装备的控制，享受捕捉瞬间的乐趣。这一切都是关于突破界限和发现你自己的摄影魔法。

会议摄影技巧：最后的话

伙计们，你有它！我拍摄精彩会议照片的 11 大技巧。无论您是经验丰富的专业人士还是使用相机的新手，这些技巧都一定会提升您的游戏水平，因此请记住它们并在您的下一次会议中使用它们。

请记住，准备是关键。不要忘记那些额外的电池、存储卡、充电器和电缆。您不想成为那个拼命寻找电源插座或向陌生人乞求备用装备的人。

接下来，控制您的相机设置，而不是使用自动。你会惊讶于它所带来的不同。

But perhaps the most important tip of all is to be unobtrusive.融入背景，成为墙壁，捕捉那些讲述会议真实故事的自然、坦率的时刻。没有人想要强迫的姿势或尴尬的微笑。保持真实！

有了这些技巧，您就可以像专业人士一样征服会议摄影世界了。走出去，捕捉那些故事，让你的镜头说话！

光圈是必不可少的相机设置。事实上，您甚至可以说它是摄影中神奇的地方。它是开启清晰度和创意可能性的关键，此外，它还能帮助您捕捉足够明亮的图像。

幸运的是，理解光圈并不困难，尤其是当您将注意力集中在几个简单的定义上时——在本文中，我将带您了解所有相关概念，包括：

  • 光圈实际上是什么（用简单易懂的术语）
  • 如何使用光圈设置来捕捉艺术图像
  • 如何为风景摄影、人像摄影等选择完美的光圈
  • 大量其他提示和技巧！

准备好让您的照片更上一层楼了吗？让我们直接开始，从最重要的问题开始：

什么是光圈？

光圈是相机镜头中的开口。 A larger hole allows more light to hit the sensor, lightening your photos.较小的孔可让较少的光线照射到传感器上，从而使照片变暗。

And by adjusting the aperture setting on your camera, you can adjust the size of the aperture (and, in turn, affect a photo's brightness).

光圈和光圈值

光圈是根据f-stops测量的，也称为f-numbers 。像这样：f/2.8、f/4、f/5.6、f/8、f/22 等。

如下图所示，f值越小，孔径越大：

现在，每个句点对应于光圈大小的一半。所以当你从 f/2.8 到 f/4 时，你将光圈减半。当你从 f/4 到 f/5.6 时，你又把光圈减半了。

（当然，要将光圈尺寸加倍，只需反方向：从 f/5.6 到 f/4，然后从 f/4 到 f/2.8。）

所以 f/2.8 是比 f/22大得多的光圈。 f/11 是比 f/4小得多的光圈。

那有意义吗？一开始可能会让人感到困惑，尤其是因为大光圈对应于较小的光圈值，反之亦然。但坚持下去，它就会成为第二天性。

光圈如何影响您的照片？

在本文的这一点上，您应该知道光圈是什么：镜头上的一个孔，它会根据您的相机设置（即，您的 f 制光圈值）而增加和减少。

但是光圈到底有什么作用呢？它如何影响你的照片？

在接下来的两节中，我将讨论光圈的主要影响：

  1. 接触
  2. 景深

光圈和曝光

您可能已经知道， 曝光是指照片的亮度。

一般来说，目标是最终得到一张不太暗也不太亮的照片；相反，您想要一张恰到好处的照片，一个有很多细节的照片。

那么光圈在哪里发挥作用呢？

Aperture is one of the three key variables that affect your exposure. （另外两个变量是快门速度和ISO 。）

还记得我上面说的吗？通过扩大光圈，可以让更多的光线进入，从而使图像变亮。通过缩小光圈，可以减少光线进入，从而使图像变暗。

因此，如果您正在拍摄美丽的日落，而您的照片总是太亮，您可以随时缩小光圈以使图像变暗。 （事实上​​，拍摄日落时使用小光圈通常是个好主意！）

而且，如果您正在拍摄森林，而您的照片总是变得又暗又暗，您始终可以扩大光圈以使图像变亮。 （如您所料，这是标准的低光摄影实践。）

当然，光圈并不是影响曝光的唯一变量。如果要使照片变亮，还可以降低快门速度或提高 ISO。如果你想让照片变暗，你可以提高快门速度或降低 ISO。

在曝光方面，将光圈扩大一个句号与将快门速度降低一个句号或将 ISO 提高一个句号具有完全相同的效果。这样做的一个关键结果是：不同的曝光变量可以相互抵消。 Increase your ISO by a stop while decreasing your aperture by a stop, and you'll end up with an identical exposure.

这里的要点是，虽然光圈确实决定曝光，但您不能孤立地考虑它。光圈、快门速度和 ISO共同为您提供曝光良好（或曝光不良）的图像。

光圈和景深

光圈还会影响照片的景深。

这到底是什么意思呢？好吧，景深 (DOF) 是您拍摄的焦点的数量。所以一张大景深的照片会让大部分图像都在焦点上，就像这样：

至于光圈，光圈越大（f 值越小！），景深越浅。

当然，您还必须记住光圈对曝光的影响，这让事情变得更复杂（但更有趣！）。

窄孔径的问题：衍射

如您所知，缩小光圈会增加景深，这意味着图像看起来更清晰。当您继续缩小光圈时，景深会继续增加——如果您要拍摄特写对象或深度很大的场景，这一点很重要。

然而，一旦光圈变得太窄，就会遇到一个问题：衍射。

衍射是一种光学特性，其中光线相互干涉。在摄影的背景下，衍射会降低清晰度，这远非理想！

幸运的是，只有当你将光圈缩小到非常远时，衍射才是真正的问题——例如，缩小到 f/16。大多数摄影师不需要在 f/16 及以上拍摄，因此衍射不是大问题。然而，有时您的场景需要很大的景深，在这种情况下您必须决定：是否缩小光圈并降低图像清晰度？或者您是否使用更大的光圈并让部分图像失焦？归根结底，选择权在你！

顺便说一下，您还有另一种选择，称为焦点堆叠，您可以在不同的焦点处捕获多张图像，然后在后期处理中将它们混合在一起。如果您经常发现自己需要超深景深效果，这可能是一个方便的解决方案，但每次拍摄后确实需要一些额外的时间。

宽孔径与窄孔径，回顾

宽孔径和窄孔径各有利弊。回顾一下：

大光圈让更多光线进入，从而增加图像曝光，并允许您使用更快的快门速度和/或更低的 ISO。它们还可以产生漂亮的浅景深效果，有助于将观看者的注意力集中在拍摄对象上。但是，很少有画面会很清晰，如果您希望以清晰的细节记录整个场景或主题，这可能是个问题。

狭窄的光圈让光线更少，如果您想确保良好的曝光，则迫使您使用较慢的快门速度和/或较高的 ISO。它们还确保您的图像具有更深的景深效果，但如果您将光圈缩小太多，您可能会因衍射而失去清晰度。

请注意：将光圈缩小几档通常会使您处于镜头的最佳位置，这意味着您的图像将尽可能清晰！每个镜头的最佳点都是不同的，所以如果你想以最锐利的光圈拍摄，我鼓励你对你拥有的每个镜头进行一些测试。

最大和最小光圈

大多数镜头都允许您从多个不同的光圈值中进行选择，例如 f/5.6、f/8 和 f/16。但是，您可以使用的光圈因产品而异，并且每个镜头都具有最大光圈和最小光圈。

镜头的最大光圈是指它提供的最大光圈。因为加宽光圈可以实现美丽的浅景深效果，并让大量光线进入，因此您可以在室内和夜间拍摄，因此具有较大最大光圈的镜头往往非常受欢迎。 （具有较大最大光圈的镜头也往往相对较大、笨重且昂贵。）

最大光圈约为 f/4 的镜头被认为是平均镜头，而最大光圈为 f/2.8、f/1.8，尤其是 f/1.4 的镜头被称为“快速”。

镜头的最小光圈指的是——您猜对了！ – 它提供的最窄光圈。由于衍射在超窄光圈下是一个大问题，而且大多数拍摄者不需要大量的景深，因此最小光圈往往不如最大光圈重要。常见的最小光圈包括 f/16、f/22 和 f/32。

如果您想知道镜头的最大和最小光圈，您可以随时查看制造商的规格表，尽管最大光圈通常列为镜头名称的一部分。例如，400mm f/2.8 镜头的最大光圈为 f/2.8，而 35mm f/1.4 镜头的最大光圈为 f/1.4。

调整相机的光圈

现在您已经做到了这一点，您可能想知道：

您如何实际更改相机的光圈？你必须做什么？

幸运的是，调整光圈很容易。您只需将相机的拍摄模式设置为手动或光圈优先。然后旋转相关的相机拨盘以更改 f 值。 （具体的拨盘将取决于您的相机型号；如果您遇到困难，请查阅您的手册。）

哪个光圈最好？

当摄影师第一次了解光圈时，这是一个经常出现的问题。

但是正如您希望从上面的部分中了解到的那样，没有可以一直使用的最佳光圈。有时您需要较深的景深，或者您希望将太亮的照片调暗，在这种情况下，您需要使用窄光圈。其他时候你会想要浅景深或者你会想要照亮太暗的镜头，在这种情况下你需要使用大光圈。

也就是说……

有些光圈在某些类型中得到一致使用。我将在下面简要介绍它们，首先是：

最佳风景摄影光圈

风景摄影师倾向于小光圈设置，例如 f/8、f/11，甚至 f/16。

为什么？

When you're shooting a sweeping photo of the land, sea, or sky, you often want to keep the whole shot sharp.这样，观众就可以欣赏到您宏伟场景的每一个细节。

此外，深景深让镜头感觉更真实，就像观众可以身临其境一样。

最佳人像摄影光圈

在人像摄影中，让拍摄对象完美对焦但背景漂亮且模糊会很方便。这样，您的主要主题就会脱颖而出，而背景不会分散注意力。

换句话说， 使用大光圈来确保浅景深。

这是家庭肖像摄影师、爆头摄影师、时尚摄影师等使用的技巧。

最佳微距摄影光圈

微距（即特写）摄影师往往不同意光圈。

一些微距摄影师使用非常窄的光圈，因为在高放大倍率下景深会变浅。通过使用小光圈，微距摄影师可以确保整个拍摄对象都清晰对焦，即使背景很模糊。

而其他微距摄影师则采用浅景深。他们使用非常大的光圈来获得柔焦效果。

走哪条路？这取决于你的喜好！这两种方法都很有效，并且有很多专业人士使用每种技术，所以不要过分强调它。

最佳产品摄影光圈

产品摄影师倾向于根据场景和他们所追求的外观使用宽光圈和窄光圈。

一方面，您可以使用大光圈来创建强调主题并营造更具艺术氛围的背景模糊。这在户外或更非正式的环境中拍摄产品时很常见。

或者，您可以使用小光圈来保持整个主体清晰并突出关键细节，例如产品徽标、标签设计等。出于这个原因，工作室产品摄影通常在小光圈下拍摄。

最佳街拍光圈

一些街头摄影师确实喜欢创造浅景深效果，在这种情况下，他们会使用大光圈（例如 f/1.8）。街头摄影师在低光或夜间工作时也可能会使用大光圈拍摄。

然而，许多认真的街拍者使用区域对焦，这涉及预先设置焦点并依靠深景深来广撒网并使主体在整个场景中保持清晰。

区域聚焦的常用光圈是 f/8。如果您决定走这条路，那将是一个很好的起点！

摄影中的光圈：最后的话

掌握镜头光圈是一项技能，可以使您的图像从平凡到非凡。通过了解大光圈和窄光圈的影响，您可以塑造照片的氛围、深度和焦点 - 现在您已经读完本文，您已经准备好捕捉一些令人叹为观止的照片。

请记住，大光圈让光线进入并产生梦幻般的浅景深效果，将观众的目光吸引到拍摄对象上。 On the other hand, narrow apertures allow you to capture the full breadth of a scene, ensuring every intricate element is sharp and in focus.

如果您仍然有点困惑，那没关系。拿起你的相机，做一些实验。找一个主题——一个苹果效果很好！ – 并用不同的光圈拍摄。观察景深的变化。

很快，它会点击。你的照片将（真的！）再也不会一样了。

Now over to you:

您对摄影中的光圈有任何疑问或提示吗？在下面的评论中分享它们！

光圈摄影常见问题解答

光圈如何影响照片？

光圈以两种方式直接影响照片：它调整曝光（即亮度），它影响景深（即图像中的锐度窗口）。更大的光圈让更多的光线进入，并提供更浅的景深。更窄的光圈让更少的光线进入，并提供更深的景深。

是小光圈好还是大光圈好？

这取决于你的目标！较低（较宽）的光圈会增加曝光和背景模糊的强度。更高（更窄）的光圈会减少曝光并使照片的大部分保持清晰。两种方法都有其优点。

大多数摄影师使用什么光圈？

摄影师使用许多不同的光圈设置——这完全取决于场景，更不用说他们所追求的效果了。风景拍摄者倾向于使用更窄的光圈，例如 f/8-f/16，以保持整个场景清晰。人像摄影师倾向于使用更大的光圈，例如 f/1.4-f/2.8，以隔离主体并创建美丽的背景模糊。但即使风景摄影师偶尔也会使用大光圈，反之亦然！重要的是要了解孔径的不同影响；这样，您就可以在每个新场景中做出明智的决定。

我怎么知道要使用什么光圈？

考虑曝光和景深。如果您在低光照条件下工作，因此需要提高曝光度，大光圈通常会有帮助。如果您想获得浅景深，大光圈也不错。另一方面，如果您想要图像中的景深较深，则窄光圈是理想的选择。

什么光圈给出最清晰的图像？

这因镜头而异，但总的来说，f/8 左右的光圈往往非常锐利。如果捕捉超清晰的图像对您很重要，请对您的镜头进行一些测试。

一切都在什么光圈下？

这取决于场景和你的焦点。 f/16 等窄光圈会增加场景的锐度，但如果您需要确定整个场景都清晰对焦，我建议使用超焦距计算器。

更高的光圈会产生更清晰的照片吗？

不必要。更高（更窄）的光圈可确保更多场景清晰对焦，但如果您不使用正确的拍摄技术或使用太慢的快门速度，图像可能会变得模糊。此外，较高的孔径会导致衍射，这会降低清晰度。

The post 10 Tips for Capturing Dramatic Skies in Your Landscape Photography appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Hillary Grigonis .

The best landscape photos tend to feature stunning skies full of texture, color, and mood. However, finding and recording that elusive drama can be a tricky endeavor, and that's why we wrote this article: to share tried-and-true methods for capturing dramatic skies in your landscape shots.

From stormy clouds and fiery sunsets to reflections and long exposures, there are endless possibilities when it comes to capturing jaw-dropping skies. We'll dive deep into the techniques that will help you seek out those majestic cloud formations and infuse your photos with intensity, depth, and a touch of the extraordinary.

Whether you're a seasoned pro or just starting your photography journey, we'll equip you with everything you need to elevate your compositions to sky-high heights. Let's dive right in, starting with my first tip:

1. Time it right

If you want to capture skies filled with drama, timing plays a crucial role. While you may not need the split-second precision required to capture a toddler's smile or a wide receiver's catch, being mindful of timing can give you an edge. Some skies can appear dull and flat, while others exude incredible drama, and by aligning your shooting with these dramatic moments, you can elevate your photography game.

So what kind of skies offer the most captivating drama? Stormy skies, as we'll explore in the next section, are undoubtedly great. But partially cloudy skies during sunrise and sunset also hold immense potential. They can transform into a breathtaking palette of colors and give the landscape a magical glow.

Partially cloudy skies often offer fiery hues during sunset, but don't be too quick to pack up after the sun dips below the horizon – drama can still unfold during the blue hour .

On the flip side, flat, overcast skies tend to be uninspiring and lackluster, so it's best to steer clear of them. Similarly, clear blue skies, while pleasant, don't typically offer much drama. It's wise to avoid them too.

To ensure you have the ideal conditions for your landscape photography outing, consider using a reliable weather app. Check it a few days and a few hours in advance to stay on top of the forecast.

However, keep in mind that forecasts aren't infallible. Get in the habit of looking up at the sky – you never know when unexpected and awe-inspiring opportunities might present themselves.

2. Head out during stormy weather

When storms are on the way, the skies truly come alive with color, texture, and mood. So if the weather forecast predicts rain, don't succumb to the temptation of staying indoors. Embrace the challenge and seize the opportunity to capture nature's raw power.

Of course, safety should always be paramount during these outings. If you see lightning or if the driving conditions become treacherous, turn back – no photo is worth risking your life!

Protecting your gear from the elements is also important. Use a raincover to shield your cameras and lenses from moisture, and ensure your backpack is also protected by waterproof materials. Also, carry a soft towel to delicately wipe away any droplets that fall on your equipment.

A professional trick to minimize exposure of your lens to the elements is to keep it covered until the last moment. By maintaining your lens cap in place until you're ready to press the shutter, you can shield it from raindrops and minimize the need for constant wiping. This small but effective technique ensures that your lens remains clear and ready to capture the scene at the perfect moment!

Pro tip: There's something especially captivating about the dramatic interplay between dark, stormy clouds and the ethereal light that breaks through their seams. Stormy clouds with sunlight shining through is a recipe for success, but it can be infrequent and fleeting – so if you're after that beautiful combination of storm and sunlight, you'll need to exercise real patience.

3. Shoot in RAW

When it comes to creating stunning landscape photos with dramatic skies, one essential aspect often overlooked by beginners is the choice of file format. Many budding photographers default to shooting in JPEG, unaware of the significant limitations this compressed format imposes on their shots.

Instead, I highly encourage you to shoot your landscape files in RAW , which will preserve every nuance of color and tonal detail your camera captures. By retaining all the data from the moment of capture, RAW empowers you to breathe life into your photographs in post-processing. You can make dramatic adjustments to the colors and tones in a RAW photo – and you can even bring back details that initially appear lost to over- and underexposure.

Granted, working with RAW files demands a bit more effort. These files are larger in size and require processing before they can be shared or printed. Yet if you're serious about landscape photography, the extra steps are a small price to pay!

4. Try the wrong white balance

Photography rules are sometimes meant to be broken, including rules about always using the correct white balance .

You see, the wrong white balance setting can create a more dramatic sky. This is especially true when shooting toward the beginning or end of the day – using a different white balance preset will adjust the color of the sky.

Auto, Cloudy, and Shade white balance presets will get you an orangish sunset with a light blue sky (with slight variations in warmth depending on the setting you choose). A fluorescent setting, on the other hand, will typically turn an orange sunset purple with a brilliant blue sky. Tungsten offers a similar effect but with even deeper colors.

Using Kelvin temperatures to adjust your white balance results in even greater control over the colors in the sky. At around 5500K, you'll usually capture a sunny sky with an accurate white balance – that is, where things that are white are still white in the picture, and where things that are gray are still gray in the picture.

A higher temperature – 6500K, for example – will give the land an orange glow but also enhance the colors in a sunset. A cooler temperature, on the other hand (eg, 3000K), will play up the blues and purples. By using the Kelvin scale, you have more options for picking a white balance setting that best captures the colors in your photos.

If you overdo things by making the shot too warm or too cool, you can easily adjust a RAW photo in post-processing until you find the color temperature that best fits the image. Therefore, if you have a landscape photo that you already shot in RAW, open it and try different white balance presets. You can see firsthand how shooting with a different white balance would have impacted the shot!

5. Compose for the sky

When the sky is more dramatic than the land, why not use that to determine your composition ?

Pay attention to where you place the horizon when you are composing your shot. Use the rule of thirds to imagine the image is divided into threes, then place the horizon on one of those horizontal lines. If you are shooting a photo with an average-looking sky, try placing the horizon on the upper third of the image, so more of the land is included in the photo, like this:

But if the sky is really dramatic, take advantage of that and include more of it in the frame – by placing the horizon on the lower third:

By including more of the sky in the shot, you'll emphasize its colors and texture while forcing the viewer to spend more time looking it over.

And if you want to really display that sky, consider using a minimalist compositional technique, where you fill the entire frame with the sky but for a small spot of land at the bottom.

6. Use a filter

There are two filters every landscape photographer should have in their camera bag in order to capture more dramatic skies.

The first is a graduated neutral density filter . Now, a regular neutral density filter is like putting sunglasses over your lens – it limits the light coming in for bright scenes or long exposures. But a graduated neutral density filter places that darkening effect only on a portion of the image. And by positioning the dark portion of the filter over a bright sky, you can properly expose the entire scene.

Without a graduated neutral density filter, the sky will often be overexposed and bland, or the land will be underexposed and dark. With the filter, you can achieve an exposure that works for both portions of the scene. The only downside is that graduated neutral density filters don't work as well with an uneven horizon, like when shooting a cityscape. Graduated neutral density filters come in both circular and square formats, but the square is often preferred because you can place the horizon anywhere in the frame.

The second filter landscape photographers should use to capture more dramatic skies is a polarizing filter . Polarizing filters work by adjusting the reflected light coming through your camera lens. Since the sky is blue because of this reflected light, turning the front of the polarizing filter will adjust the intensity of the blues in the sky. Since polarizing filters only affect reflected light, they can still be used when mountains or buildings make the horizon uneven. Polarizing filters are also great for enhancing or removing reflections on water or other shiny surfaces.

7. Experiment with motion blur and long exposures

Long exposures aren't just for photographing waterfalls. If you use a long enough shutter speed , the clouds will blur, too, creating a sky of wispy streaks and a slight feeling of motion.

To capture motion blur in the clouds, you'll need to use a long shutter speed. The best settings will depend a bit on the weather and how much motion blur you'd like, but you can try starting with a two-minute exposure and adjusting up or down from there.

If you are shooting during the day, you may not be able to balance out a two-minute exposure with a narrow-enough aperture or a low-enough ISO ; instead, you'll end up with a photo that's way too bright.

So how do photographers capture motion blur in the clouds when the photo obviously wasn't taken at dusk or dawn? They use a neutral density filter – which helps block out some of the light so that you can set a long exposure during the day.

(Note that a neutral density filter is similar to a graduated neutral density filter, but the entire filter is dark instead of just half of the filter).

8. Use a graduated filter tool when editing

While it's always best to get shots right in camera, there are a few editing tools that can improve the sky in your landscape photos. One of those tools is a graduated filter, which you can find inside Photoshop, Lightroom, Capture One, Adobe Camera Raw, and more.

With the graduated filter, you can apply an adjustment that targets the sky in your photo. Like a physical graduated filter, the effect will only cover the top portion of the image and gradually fade away, making it possible to create natural-looking edits.

This tool can be used to adjust the exposure, creating an effect much like an actual graduated neutral density filter. But the tool can also adjust contrast, saturation, clarity, sharpness, and color. It opens up a lot of possibilities for applying edits just to the sky for more drama – creating effects that sometimes can't be done in the field.

9. Test out black and white

Dramatic sky photos tend to be in color, simply because much of the drama comes from colors – but it's sometimes a good idea to deviate from this approach and instead try a black-and-white conversion.

Why choose black and white ? Well, a monochromatic palette can work wonders in enhancing the texture and intricacy of the sky, thereby intensifying the overall drama of your composition. By stripping away the distraction of color, you'll be left with the raw essence of the clouds and will allow them to command attention with their rich tonal range and contrasting forms.

One note: Before diving into the world of B&W, it is crucial to ensure that your sky offers enough detail and texture. A featureless expanse of clouds may end up looking rather lackluster in monochrome. Apply the conversion to photos of skies with well-defined shapes, layers, and intricate patterns.

If you don't have much editing experience, don't worry; adding a B&W effect generally takes a single click of a button. And for more serious editors, advanced tools often let you fine-tune your conversions by individually adjusting various color channels.

Plus, if you don't like the results, you can always revert back to the original shot, assuming you're using a non-destructive editing program.

10. Look for reflections

Reflections can't directly enhance the drama in the sky – but they can create a captivating visual experience that allows the sky to be expanded within the frame.

To start, seek out reflective elements that harmonize with your composition. Tranquil lakes, shimmering ponds, and even small pools or puddles of water can all work great, though I certainly encourage you to be creative.

Once you've identified a reflective surface, take the time to adjust your shooting angle. Explore different perspectives to find the most compelling composition that showcases the interplay between the captivating sky and its mirrored counterpart. Be patient and persistent, as minor adjustments can make a significant difference in the final result.

If you're struggling to get a nice shot, try experimenting with your camera's distance to the reflective element. By getting in close, you can create a more immersive composition that draws viewers into the frame. On the other hand, ensuring the reflection occupies a smaller portion of the frame while letting the primary subject dominate can instill a sense of grandeur and vastness.

Capturing dramatic skies in your landscape photos: final words

The sky can make or break a landscape photo! From timing and composition to filters and post-processing, when you consider the sky as you shoot, you'll end up with more dramatic, frame-worthy shots.

Remember, the key to capturing dramatic skies lies in being prepared, patient, and open to experimentation. Nature is unpredictable and will reward those who are willing to wait for the perfect light, brave the stormy weather, and embrace the unexpected. Don't be afraid to get out of your comfort zone and try new perspectives, angles, and post-processing techniques!

Now it's time to pick up your camera and embark on your own personal quest to capture the most dramatic skies the world has to offer. Hit the road, explore new horizons, and chase those epic moments that will leave your viewers breathless.
